page_analysis.text_content:
Grade

When measuring | Use | Which is defined as | Illus.
---|---|---|---
The height of a structure on land with natural slope ≤ 10% | Existing Grade | for each building or structure, the lowest point of adjacent ground elevation prior to grading or fill | Fig 44 on this page
The height of a structure on land with natural slope > 10% | Grade | adjacent ground elevation of the finished or existing grade, whichever is lower--at any point of the structure | Fig 45 on this page
A daylight plane | Average grade | average of the grade at the midpoint of the building and the grade at the closest point on the abutting site | Figs 20-21 pp. 26-27

Fig 44 Existing vs. Finished grade

Height measured to top of roof material of the highest peak
Finished grade (after fill)
Existing grade (before fill)
Lowest point of ground elevation before fill (existing grade) adjacent to the structure

Fig 45 Height limits for structures on slopes greater than 10%
30' above existing grade
30' above finished
Existing grade (before fill)
Height
Height
The structure must comply with the lower of the two limits at all points along the slope

Fig 46 Comparison of different grades

visual_elements.description: A table with four columns: 'When measuring', 'Use', 'Which is defined as', and 'Illus.'. It lists three rows describing how to measure grade for structures on land with natural slope ≤ 10%, > 10%, and a daylight plane, including references to figures 44, 45, and 20-21 (pp. 26-27).

Fig 44 Existing vs. Finished grade: A side elevation drawing of a house showing the height measured to the top of the roof material of the highest peak. It shows the finished grade (after fill), existing grade (before fill), and the lowest point of ground elevation before fill adjacent to the structure.

Fig 45 Height limits for structures on slopes greater than 10%: A side elevation drawing of two houses on a slope with arrows indicating '30' above existing grade' and '30' above finished'. It shows existing grade (before fill) and height measurements. A note states the structure must comply with the lower of the two limits at all points along the slope.
Fig 46 Comparison of different grades: A graph with lines labeled 1:10 10%, 3:10 30%, 5:10 50%, and 10:10 100%, showing slope comparisons.

technical_specifications.parameter: Natural slope for existing grade measurement

additional_notes: Page number 47 at bottom right corner.
All text is clear and legible with no handwritten annotations or stamps.
The table uses bold font for column headers and some bold text in the 'Which is defined as' column for emphasis (e.g., 'lower--at any point of the structure').

qualifiers.text: The structure must comply with the lower of the two limits at all points along the slope

logical_relationships.expression: The structure must comply with the lower of the two limits at all points along the slope
logical_relationships.ambiguity_note: The exact logical operator is implied as AND with a minimum selection (lower of two limits), but not explicitly stated.

execution_sequence.action: Determine the height limits based on existing grade and finished grade
Ensure the structure height complies with the lower of the two height limits at all points along the slope
